items.title: The interplay of future emissions and geophysical uncertainties for projections of sea-level rise
items.body:
Article

Published: 10 October 2025

The interplay of future emissions and geophysical uncertainties for projections of sea-level rise
                    Chloe Darnell 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-4390-26561, Lisa Rennels 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-5307-93362 na1, Frank Errickson 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-2195-94243 na1, Tony Wong 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-7304-38834 na1 & …Vivek Srikrishnan 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-0049-38051 Show authors

Nature Climate Change

(2025)Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Climate-change impactsProjection and prediction

AbstractUncertainty in future CO2 emissions and the geophysical response to emissions drives variability in future sea-level rise. However, the relative contributions of emissions and geophysical dynamics (for example, Antarctic Ice Sheet (AIS) tipping points) to future sea-level projections are not well understood. Here we disentangle their relative importance by propagating an ensemble of CO2 emissions trajectories through a calibrated carbon cycle–climate–sea-level model chain. Without negative emissions, the CO2 emissions trajectory, particularly the timing of when emissions are reduced, becomes the primary driver of sea-level variability between 2065 and 2075. Accelerated AIS melting greatly influences the sensitivity of global mean sea-level rise to time-averaged and integrated temperature changes. The most important geophysical uncertainties associated with the risk of exceeding sea-level thresholds are the threshold corresponding to accelerated AIS melting and equilibrium climate sensitivity. Our results highlight the need for both adaptation and rapid decarbonization to manage the risks posed by SLR.

You have full access to this article via your institution.
            
                
    
        
            
                Download PDF

MainPolicy targets aimed at reducing the impacts of climate change often emphasize mitigating greenhouse gas emissions. The efficacy of managing future climate risks through emissions reductions is subject to a number of climatic- and biogeochemical-system uncertainties, and to delays in the climate response1,2. Hypothesized accelerated melting of both the Antarctic and Greenland Ice Sheets (AIS and GIS) raises questions about the ability of greenhouse gas mitigation to control the rate of global mean sea-level rise (GMSLR) given committed warming due to historical and near-term future emissions3,4,5,6,7.Although there is a roughly linear relationship between cumulative CO2 emissions and global mean temperature (GMT), other impacts, such as GMSLR, are subject to path dependencies and feedbacks that disrupt a direct relationship with cumulative emissions8. More rapid near-term emissions growth increases the amount of time ice sheets are exposed to warmer air and ocean waters. As a result, two emissions pathways with the same cumulative emissions may yield different global sea levels by a given year, depending on the interactions between the emissions pathway and the geophysical sensitivity to those emissions, such as through ice dynamics which can accelerate or decelerate melting responses to warmer oceans and atmospheres beyond the expected surface mass balance8,9.One particularly important question concerns how delaying mitigation affects the hazards associated with GMSLR, and what geophysical processes become more or less important for understanding future GMSLR risk based on the emissions trajectory. Recent work examines the impact of delayed mitigation and emissions uncertainty on sea-level contributions from the AIS10,11. Furthermore, there is evidence that the impact of high-emissions scenarios, particularly on the AIS, is unlikely to be observed this century9. Another recent study quantifies the role of delayed mitigation consistent with the Paris Agreement (including overshoot scenarios) on committed SLR12. While the impact of mitigation on GMSLR is often understood through the lens of the Representative Concentration Pathway–Shared Socioeconomic Pathway (SSP-RCP) scenarios13, these scenarios combine a number of uncertainties concerning future emissions, such as cumulative emissions/radiative forcing and the timing of emissions reduction, into a set of scenarios tractable for model intercomparison projects and other large-scale modelling efforts.To address these questions around the sensitivity of GMSLR to the timing and extent of CO2 emissions growth and decarbonization, we propagate parameterized trajectories of future CO2 emissions through a probabilistically calibrated model chain capturing uncertainties in the carbon cycle, climate responses and SLR. We use this framework to identify the sensitivity of these relative importances to features of future emissions trajectories.Effects of CO2 emissions trajectories on sea levelsWe begin by simulating sample trajectories of future CO2 emissions up to 2200 using a simple parametric model specified by the rate of near-term emissions growth, the year of peak emissions and the initial rate of decarbonization (Fig. 1a and Methods). We use this approach, instead of the SSP-RCP scenarios, to more directly incorporate and interrogate a variety of uncertainties associated with future emissions trajectories and with variability in cumulative CO2 emissions.Fig. 1: Climate and sea-level impacts from emissions ensembles: summaries of simulations.a,b, Annual CO2 emissions (a) and GMT anomaly relative to the 1850–1900 mean (b) from 2000 to 2200. The solid line is the ensemble median and the shaded ribbons are the central 90% projection interval. SSP-RCP annual emissions and IPCC AR6 temperature anomalies (averaged from 2041–2060 and 2081–2100, respectively (Supplementary Table 1)48) provided for comparison. c–f, Box plots of global mean sea-level anomalies relative to the 1995–2014 mean (c), GMSLR contributions from the AIS (d) and the GIS (e), and AIS contributions without fast dynamic processes (f). The boxes cover the 25–75% interquartile range, the central measure is the median (50% quantile) and the whiskers cover 1.5 times the interquartile range. All uncertainty ranges and box plots were derived from an ensemble of 100,000 simulations.Full size imageOur baseline distribution of emissions trajectories is broadly consistent with the emerging consensus about the likelihood of the SSP-RCPs14,15,16, with a median annual CO2 emissions in 2100 of 7 GtCO2 yr−1 (90% credible interval, 2–61 GtCO2 yr−1) and a median temperature anomaly of 2.5 °C relative to the 1850–1900 mean (1.5–3.7 °C). We use two alternative emissions trajectory distributions, labelled ‘optimistic’ and ‘pessimistic’, to examine the sensitivity of the GMSLR outcomes to differing distributions, capturing higher probabilities of either lower or more extreme emissions scenarios (Fig. 1 and Extended Data Fig. 1). Specifically, this scenario begins with a 50% probability of achieving a 2 °C warming target17; the median annual CO2 emissions in 2100 are 3 GtCO2 yr−1 (90% credible interval, 1–33 GtCO2 yr−1) and the median temperature anomaly is 2.0 °C (1.4–3.0 °C). The pessimistic scenario assigns zero probability to this mitigation level (Fig. 1a,b); the median annual CO2 emissions in 2100 are 13 GtCO2 yr−1 (90% credible interval, 2–76 GtCO2 yr−1) and the median temperature anomaly is 2.7 °C (1.8– 3.9 °C).We propagate the sampled CO2 emissions trajectories through the Simple Non-linear Earth System Model (SNEASY)18, which adds a carbon-cycle component to the Diffusion Ocean Energy Climate model (DOECLIM)19, and the Building Blocks for Relevant Ice and Climate Knowledge (BRICK) model20,21, a mechanistically motivated sea-level rise model which includes representations of AIS and GIS dynamics and other contributors of SLR (Methods). Of particular note is that BRICK includes an accelerated melting mechanism for the AIS once temperatures exceed a particular (uncertain) threshold, which is intended to capture dynamics including the hypothesized Marine Ice Cliff and Ice Sheet Instabilities and other more accepted mechanisms22,23,24. Following ref. 25, we refer to these accelerations as ‘fast dynamics.’Although some existing studies use more complex ice-sheet models to study the impact of emissions reductions11, these models pose computational challenges for large-scale uncertainty analysis26,27. We therefore use the aforementioned set of reduced-form, parsimonious models, and discuss the implications of their approximations below (for more details, see Methods and Supplementary Figs. 1 and 2). The net effect is that the baseline scenario results in GMSLR projections consistent with SSP3-7.0 and SSP5-8.5 despite GMT projections below the SSP5-8.5 range, whereas the optimistic scenario is more consistent with GMT and GMSLR projections from SSP2-4.5. We interpret our results in light of this net bias.As previously discussed, the roughly linear relationship between GMSLR rate and GMT is complicated by ice dynamics and cumulative exposure to warmer air and ocean waters. This results in a bifurcation (detected using a piecewise-linear regression; Methods) in the GMSLR projections (Fig. 2a) after a time-averaged GMT anomaly of about 0.7 °C per century. Until 0.7 °C per century, the sensitivity of GMSLR projections to warming is approximately 45 mm °C−1, which is aligned with expert elicitations and twenty-first century CMIP6 projections28. If the century-scale warming exceeds 0.7 °C, the estimated response increases by an additional 58 mm °C as a result of the contribution from the fast dynamics mechanisms. The sensitivity of GMSLR to time-integrated GMT anomalies (Fig. 2b) exhibits a similar increase after 125 °C-yr, suggesting that apparent scenario independence from CMIP6 projections29 could be an artefact of the scenario design or a limited representation of AIS dynamics. The increased non-fast dynamics sensitivity is greater than that from expert elicitations of the twenty-first century transient sensitivity and at the high end of the early twenty-first century (2016–2050) rate from CMIP6 simulations28. This is probably the result of the larger high-temperature GMSLR response from BRICK relative to the CMIP6 projections (Supplementary Fig. 2), which is primarily informed by the fast-dynamics calibration to palaeoclimatic sea-level reconstructions25; more conservative estimates would result from models that are less sensitive to the temperature gradient.Fig. 2: Sensitivity of GMSLR to temperature changes.a, Density of GMSLR rates from the 2000–2100 ensemble driven by century-scale GMT changes over that period, including best-fit linear relationships between GMSLR and GMT. The purple dot is an inferred breakpoint in the all-simulation regression (see Methods for details). b, Sensitivity of GMSLR to time-integrated GMT anomalies, following ref. 29. Bands represent the 95% prediction uncertainty (2.5–97.5 percentiles) for the regressions derived from 100,000 simulations.Full size imageThe most likely GMSLR outcomes are very sensitive to the underlying emissions distribution, although the worst-case outcomes are broadly similar. The median baseline ensemble GMSLR anomaly in 2100 is 0.8 m (90% projection interval, 0.4–1.4 m) in 2100, relative to the 1995–2014 mean (Fig. 1c). Comparatively, the other scenarios differ by relatively small GSMLR values, with median anomalies of 0.6 m (0.4–1.2 m) for the optimistic scenario and 0.9 m (0.5–1.5 m) for the pessimistic ensemble. However, by 2150 these differences become more pronounced, with median sea levels of 1.6 m (0.6–2.9 m) for the baseline scenario, 0.9 m (0.6–2.4 m) for the optimistic ensemble and 1.9 m (0.7–3.1 m) for the pessimistic ensemble. This occurs because the optimistic ensemble has a high probability of net-zero emissions before 2100. Although the worst-case outcomes are similar across emissions ensembles, the differences are attributable to the changed exposure of GIS to warmer air temperatures rather than a change in AIS melting (Fig. 1d,e) because AIS fast dynamics is inevitably triggered at higher GMTs, reducing the sensitivity to the AIS fast-dynamics temperature threshold. As SNEASY–BRICK has biases relative to the AR6 GMSLR projections (Methods), these estimates are likely to be higher than those obtained by weighting the AR6 projections to obtain similar emissions distributions. To examine how these biases might affect our conclusions, we construct an ensemble from the temperature-based AR6 SLR projections by sampling a temperature distribution based on the temperature empirical cumulative density function of our baseline ensemble30, then sampling from within that distribution. For this AR6 ensemble, the baseline ensemble’s median GMSLR anomaly is 0.6 m (0.3–1.0 m) in 2100 and 0.8 m (0.4–1.6 m) in 2150.Extreme GMSLR outcomes (for example greater than 4.0 m of GMSLR in 2200) can occur at relatively modest emissions levels, but this requires a low-probability combination of Earth-system dynamics. Global mean sea levels greater than 4.0 m by 2200 only require a cumulative emissions between 2020 and 2100 of at least 1,520 GtCO2, which is closer to low-medium SSP4-3.4 cumulative emissions during this period than the medium SSP2-4.5. This low minimum emissions level is the result of relatively extreme geophysical uncertainties; the 90% interval is 3,340–7,200 GtCO2, a lower bound roughly the cumulative emissions of the medium-high SSP4-6.0 scenario. The relatively extreme additional melt rate required upon triggering fast dynamics limits the occurrence of these outcomes despite the moderate required level of emissions.Importance of sea-level drivers over timeGeophysical uncertainties have an important role in determining sea-level outcomes even when emissions are rapidly drawn down11. As discussed in the ‘Effects of CO2 emissions trajectories on sea levels’ section, the occurrence of extreme SLR and the relative importance of the GIS as compared to the AIS as sources of future SLR also vary based on both emissions and geophysical uncertainties. This raises the question of what geophysical uncertainties are most important for future sea levels, both in the near term and longer term, and over what period geophysical uncertainties are primary determinants of future sea levels.To rank the importance of relevant emissions and geophysical uncertainties over time, we perform a global sensitivity analysis31,32,33 to identify the contribution of each set of uncertainties to the GMSLR prediction at 5-year intervals from 2050 to 2200 (Methods). We emphasize that the resulting rankings do not reflect the amount of GMSLR contributed from each source (Fig. 1), but rather the degree to which accounting for these uncertainties improves the prediction of GMSLR (Methods). As a result, these rankings quantify how learning about the relevant uncertainties can help improve predictions of GMSLR.The dynamics of future CO2 emissions become the single most important feature between 2065 and 2075, accounting for approximately 25–29% of the total uncertainty and rising to almost 50% by 2150 (Fig. 3a and Extended Data Fig. 2). Although the climate system and AIS uncertainty importances are slightly lower than the emissions importance in 2065 (Extended Data Fig. 2), the values are close enough that their rank ordering could be switched by models that had different biases than SNEASY and BRICK. Given that SNEASY tends to underestimate effective CO2 radiative forcings and has narrower equilibrium climate sensitivity (ECS) distribution than in AR6 (Supplementary Fig. 1), the magnitude of the true importances of carbon-cycle and climate-system uncertainties may also be larger. However, in 2075, the emissions system is unambiguously the most important factor. The separation of global mean sea-level trajectories due to emissions variability is consistent with previous analyses in that the ranking of Earth-system components that contribute the most to GMSLR variability changes across emissions scenarios34. These results are broadly consistent with the AR6 ensemble (Supplementary Fig. 3). This pattern holds for the optimistic and pessimistic ensembles, although in these, emissions are slightly less important owing to the lower variability of the emissions distributions (Fig. 3b). Climate system uncertainty (primarily consisting of the ECS, the rate heat is absorbed into the oceans and the uncertain magnitude of the cooling effect of aerosols) is consistently important across the emissions ensembles because it directly moderates the translation of emissions into air and ocean temperature increases. However, the importance of the climate system grows over time for the optimistic emissions scenario relative to the others as these uncertainties directly impact whether a reduction in emissions in the next few decades is sufficient to reduce temperatures enough to minimize GMSLR. The conservative GMT estimates of SNEASY relative to AR6 probably result in an underestimation of the importance of the carbon-cycle and climate-system uncertainties relative to a similar decomposition conducted with CMIP6 simulations.Fig. 3: Time-varying feature importances for global mean sea-level projections.The evolution of grouped Shapley indices across uncertain drivers of global mean sea-level projections. a, Group uncertainty importance for the baseline scenario. b–e, Differences from the baseline importances over time for the optimistic and pessimistic scenarios for emissions (b), climate (c), AIS (d) and GIS (e). A list of the most influential individual parameters for each scenario is provided in Extended Data Table 1.Full size imageThe AIS and GIS uncertainties change in importance over time in opposite directions, reflecting the growing impact of uncertainty surrounding the triggering and speed of fast ice dynamics, which can result in high GMSLRs even for relatively low emissions (Fig. 2b). Although no AIS parameters are closely tied to the projected GMSLR in 2050, the fast dynamics triggering temperature is the third most important parameter by 2060 (after ECS and the rate of ocean thermal expansion). The AIS trigger temperature remains one of the most important parameters through 2200 (generally after the year in which emissions peak and ECS), along with the rate by which AIS melting increases. We note that ice dynamics in GIS are not explicitly modelled by BRICK; these would certainly increase the importance of GIS uncertainties as uncertain accelerated melting would increase the range of GIS contributions to GMSLR later in the projection period28 and might overshadow the importance of AIS uncertainties given the higher volumes of SLR contributed by GIS by 2200 (Fig. 1d,e). The incorporation of these uncertainties might also help correct the high bias of GIS projections at lower temperatures by allowing for a more rapid GIS response as GMT increases (Supplementary Fig. 2b,c).Delaying mitigation reduces the geophysical safe operating spaceCharacterizing the uncertainty associated with the timing of sea-level thresholds is another key challenge for SLR adaptation planning. Thresholds that may be reached sooner allow for less time to adapt, whereas thresholds with a large amount of uncertainty create different challenges related to learning and the timing of adaptation. For example, we focus on the probability of exceeding three thresholds, namely GMSLR anomalies of 0.4, 0.5 and 0.6 m (relative to the 1995–2014 mean) by 2100. A (local) SLR increase of 0.5 m can result in a 10-fold amplification of the entire flood risk distribution at most global tide gauges and a 100-fold amplification at more than half35. Identifying the conditions under which SLR thresholds are reached (and when) is useful for adaptation decision-making given the wide variety of SLR-relevant uncertainties36.We adopt the concept of a geophysical ‘safe operating space’. A set of human-controlled variables is ‘safe’ if the corresponding outcomes are sufficiently far from triggering undesirable outcomes37,38. Here, our control variables are emissions trajectories, and we measure ‘safety’ through the probability of exceeding GMSLR levels due to geophysical uncertainties, namely whether an emissions trajectory has an estimated 50% or larger probability of avoiding these thresholds. We emphasize that these thresholds, and therefore the associated spaces, are not ‘safe’ in a colloquial sense because they exceed estimates for tolerable levels of GMSLR for many island and coastal populations and ecosystems; we borrow the term for its conceptual applicability for an arbitrary threshold.Delaying a reduction in CO2 emissions by even a decade erodes the geophysical ‘safe operating space’ associated with avoiding any threshold of GMSLR in 2100 (Fig. 4). The most important uncertainty influencing the probability of exceeding these thresholds is the year in which emissions peak (Supplementary Fig. 4), while the most important geophysical uncertainties are the ECS and the strength of aerosol cooling effects. Because the aerosol scaling factor is highly correlated with ECS39, we focus on the ECS and the AIS fast dynamics temperature threshold, which becomes important for the 0.6-m threshold (Supplementary Fig. 4). As BRICK tends to reach SLR thresholds earlier than other SLR model families40, we emphasize the general trends in how delaying mitigation reduces the safe operating space, rather than the specific locations of these spaces.Fig. 4: Delayed mitigation reduces the ‘safe operating space’ for avoiding GMSLR thresholds.a–c, AIS fast dynamics (FD) threshold for GMSLRs of 0.4 m (a), 0.5 m (b) and 0.6 m (c) in 2100. Contour lines separate the predicted values of ECS and the temperature threshold at which AIS fast dynamics is triggered for scenarios peaking in 2030, 2040, 2050 and 2060. GMSLR anomalies are relative to the 1995–2014 mean. Regions above and to the left of the contours have a <50% probability of exceeding the associated threshold, while regions below and to the left of the contours have a >50% probability of exceeding that threshold. The marginal probability distributions of both ECS and the Antarctic temperature threshold are provided for context about the probability of parameter values.Full size imageIf emissions are not reduced by 2050, there is a >50% probability of reaching the 0.4-m threshold regardless of the involved geophysical uncertainties. The safe operating space for the 0.5-m threshold is primarily influenced by ECS; the decrease in our identified ‘safe’ ECS from around 3.5 °C when emissions peak in 2030 to 2 °C when this is delayed until 2060 illustrates how a failure to mitigate emissions erodes the safe operating space.Thresholds of 0.6 m and greater involve a more complex safe operating space entailing interactions across a number of geophysical uncertainties. Although the specifics of the identified safe operating spaces are subject to the biases of the SNEASY–BRICK model, we expect that the key insight (that decadal-scale delays in emissions reduction result in requiring considerably more geophysical luck to avoid risk-relevant thresholds) is robust and these thresholds can be identified with similar modelling frameworks. For example, using the AR6 ensemble primarily reduces the threshold associated with a given safe operating space by approximately 0.1 m (because the probability of exceeding these thresholds is reduced) rather than qualitatively changing it (Supplementary Fig. 5).DiscussionOne key challenge in climate risk management is evaluating mitigation and adaptation as complementary parts of a risk-management portfolio. This is partially due to the computational complexity of spatially explicit climate models, which restricts their ability to resolve the implications (including uncertainties) of emissions trajectories resulting from simulations of mitigation scenarios26. This limitation can be somewhat circumvented for climate impacts which are directly related to step changes in GMT because they can be projected with high degrees of confidence based on GMT anomalies and therefore cumulative emissions41. These challenges in characterizing the full set of future emissions pathways increase the difficulty of designing adaptive management strategies for the associated sea-level risks42,43.However, while the GMSLR is subject to a number of path dependencies that tie the timing of projected sea levels to assumptions about future emissions trajectories, one of our key findings is that the set of influential geophysical uncertainties is largely robust to these differences. In addition to uncertainties contributing to GMT change, our analysis highlights the importance of uncertainties surrounding ice dynamics, which have a strong influence on the sensitivity of GMSLR to cumulative emissions and GMT8,24.One caveat is that our analysis excludes the possible impacts of negative-emissions technologies (NETs)44,45. NETs have a major role in planning potential emissions pathways that keep temperature anomalies below −1.5 or 2 °C (refs. 44,45,46). Although our framework allows for the interpretation that emissions reductions could be the result of NET deployment, we do not allow for annual emissions to go below zero. Given the moderate probability of triggering AIS instabilities unless decarbonization begins in the next few decades, NETs may be required to avoid crossing even the relatively modest thresholds considered in the ‘Delaying mitigation reduces the geophysical safe operating space’ section, which still pose existential risks for many small islands and coastal regions47.Nevertheless, our study highlights how transparency about emissions distributions, or better yet the underlying assumptions, can allow analysts and planners to interpret the associated GMSLR projections consistently with their beliefs and needs. Rather than treating the SSP-RCPs discretely (or as equally likely), these scenarios can be weighted to explore the role of different probability assumptions on impacts30. However, as we have seen for GMSLR, this approach is not completely sufficient, owing to the role of emissions trajectory dynamics, rather than cumulative emissions alone, in shaping the probability of exceeding key GMSLR tipping points. Indeed, observations about when emissions are likely to track downwards are likely to have a strong role in shaping assessments of sea-level adaptation needs.MethodsEmissions modelWe model CO2 emissions using a simple parametric model with three parameters: a growth rate γg, a year in which emissions peak τ and a decline rate γd. Prior to year τ, we assume emissions increase quadratically, and after τ, they decrease logistically with an asymptote of 0. Mathematically, if q(t) are the CO2 emissions in GtCO2 in year t,$$q(t)=\left\{\begin{array}{l}\begin{array}{rcl}q(t-1)+{\gamma }_{{\rm{g}}}(\tau -t) & \mathrm{if} & t\le \tau \end{array}\\ \begin{array}{rcl}q(t-1)-\frac{2q(\tau ){\gamma }_{{\rm{d}}}\exp ({\gamma }_{{\rm{d}}}(t-\tau ))}{{(\exp ({\gamma }_{{\rm{d}}}(t-\tau ))+1)}^{2}} & \mathrm{if} & t > \tau \end{array}\end{array}\right.$$
                    (1)
                This model represents the following features of decarbonized energy systems:
                
                  1.
                  
                    increasing emissions that plateau due to increased decarbonization efforts and energy efficiency;
                  
                
                
                  2.
                  
                    Varying rates of decline after emissions peak in year τ which represent different decarbonization efficiencies and penetration rates of technologies available at that time.
                  
                
              The specific parametric form is not intended to reflect any specific pathway produced by, for example, an integrated assessment model, but to capture a range of plausible emissions values in the future. Example trajectories to illustrate the ranges of states of the world (SOWs) and approximations for the SSP-RCP scenarios are shown in Supplementary Fig. 6. We opt for this parametric framework as opposed to using emissions generated by an integrated assessment model so we can focus on the properties of the emissions trajectories, rather than their underlying drivers, which are subject to choices and assumptions related to model structure which might influence the relationship between the parametric scenario and the resulting emissions.To develop our ensembles of emissions SOWs, we begin by developing probability distributions of cumulative CO2 emissions from 2022 to 2100. We use three scenarios, corresponding to baseline, optimistic and pessimistic views on decarbonization. The baseline scenario corresponds to a 50% probability that we will achieve decarbonization levels consistent with a 2 °C carbon budget17 of 1,223 GtCO2, and otherwise that cumulative emissions consistent with SSP4-6.0 are most likely, based on the summary in ref. 49. The optimistic scenario assigns a 75% probability to the 2 °C carbon budget, and expects that missing this target will still result in emissions close to this level. The pessimistic scenario assigns no specific probability to reaching the 2 °C carbon budget, and reflects expectations that emissions will tend to be at the higher end of the SSP-RCP range, with a mean cumulative emissions of SSP3-7.0.Emissions distributionsWe then obtain parameter distributions for our model through probabilistic inversion50,51, treating each emissions scenario as akin to an expert assessment of future CO2 emissions. This procedure involves updating a previous parameter distribution using Markov chain Monte Carlo. We place the following independent prior distributions on these parameters:
                
                  1.
                  
                    γg ≈ TruncNorm(0.004, 0.0075; 0.001, ∞)
                  
                
                
                  2.
                  
                    τ ≈ TruncNorm(2070, 25; 2030, 2200)
                  
                
                
                  3.
                  
                    γd ≈ TruncNorm(0.07, 0.05; 0.001, 0.2)
                  
                
              We chose these priors to balance two competing objectives: allowing the different emissions scenarios to outweigh the priors in the associated inversions while constraining the most extreme outcomes.We then draw 500,000 post-burn-in posterior simulations using an adaptive Metropolis–Hastings algorithm, assessing convergence to the stationary distribution through visual and quantitative (Gelman–Rubin diagnostic) assessments of multiple chains. The resulting parameter distributions are shown in Supplementary Fig. 7, and the resulting emissions ensemble for each scenario are shown in Extended Data Fig. 1. Notably, owing to the Bayesian update involved in probabilistic inversion, the resulting emissions distributions do not align precisely with the distributions specified above.Although these trajectories neglect non-CO2 greenhouse gas emissions, we obtain the radiative forcings from these emissions from the Shared Socioeconomic Pathway scenario closest to the given CO2 trajectory in a given year.Climate and sea-level modelsWe model the geophysical impacts of CO2 emissions by coupling models of the carbon cycle, the global climate and SLR. For the sake of brevity, here we give a quick, equation-free overview of the relevant models and processes, with references for full details.We model the carbon cycle using SNEASY18. SNEASY includes ocean and terrestrial carbon-cycle components that respond to temperature changes through feedback with the climate module. The ocean carbon cycle consists of a four-layer diffusion model, with an uncertain thermocline transfer rate at which carbon diffuses from the top layer (the atmosphere and mixed ocean surface) to the deeper layers. The terrestrial carbon cycle accounts for the leafy vegetation, living wood, detritus and soil carbon sinks. Increases in temperature influence the rate of carbon respiration according to an uncertainty respiration sensitivity, and the carbon fertilization rate of plants is also treated as uncertain.Changes to the global climate system are based on DOECLIM19, which is a globally aggregated energy balance model. DOECLIM couples a zero-dimensional atmosphere to a one-dimensional (vertical) ocean model. The global mean surface temperature represents an area-weighted average of land and sea surface temperature anomalies that result from an induced radiative forcing. Ocean heat content changes by vertical diffusion from the atmosphere and sea surface into the deeper ocean. The uncertain aerosol indirect effect (due to aerosol–cloud feedbacks) is modelled through a multiplicative scaling factor for aerosol forcing.The atmospheric temperature and ocean heat content from SNEASY are then used to force SLR dynamics. SLR is simulated using BRICK20,25. BRICK models the following contributors to absolute GMSLR: (1) thermal expansion, (2) small glaciers and ice caps (GIC), (3) GIS, (4) AIS and (5) land-water storage (LWS). Thermal expansion is calculated as a linear function of the change in ocean heat52. The GIC module is the same as in the MAGICC model53. The GIC melt rate is a function of the difference between the GMT and an equilibrium temperature and the unmelted GIC volume. The GIS module models the GIS contribution by estimating an equilibrium volume and the e-folding timescale of the volume response, both of which depend on the current global mean temperature anomaly. The AIS module is based on the two-dimensional Danish Center for Earth System Science AIS model (DAIS)54, which uses a two-dimensional ice-sheet geometry to model contributions from (1) incident precipitation, (2) runoff of ice melt, (3) ice flow and (4) ice-sheet disintegration from rising and warming sea levels. The BRICK representation of AIS adds a fast-dynamics component to DAIS that is intended to represent melt accelerations due to ice-sheet instabilities, which might correspond to but are not intended to explicitly represent marine ice sheet and ice cliff instabilities (MISI and MICI)22. The fast-dynamics component includes an uncertain triggering temperature threshold and rate of melting increase when Antarctic surface temperatures are above the threshold. Finally, LWS is modelled as a random contribution each year.We use a coupled version of SNEASY–DOECLIM–BRICK in the Mimi integrated assessment modelling framework21, which is probabilistically calibrated to palaeo and instrumental observations25,39. In particular, the AIS module is first constrained to produce ice volumes within prescribed palaeoclimatic windows25, which updates the relevant prior parameter distributions. This initially updated distribution is further updated via Markov chain Monte Carlo using observations of CO2 concentrations and fluxes, GMTs, ocean heat content, GIS and AIS volumes, and global mean sea levels. The data used for the calibration are provided in Supplementary Table 2. The likelihoods of the individual observations are given by AR(1) functions to account for accumulations of discrepancies between the model simulations and observations55.The prior distributions for this calibration are specified in refs. 20,25, but in particular were chosen to be relatively wide and uninformative. The end result is a set of 10,000,000 post-burn-in samples from the joint posterior distribution that capture correlations across the individual parameter distributions.The ability to predict the historic climate record can be thought of as a minimum benchmark for confidence in a model’s future projections. SNEASY has well-calibrated GMT hindcasts (Supplementary Fig. 7). However, its reduced form includes approximations that result in individual-component biases. SNEASY’s overall predictive skill is the result of compensations between its carbon cycle, which produces high- biased CO2 concentrations and radiative forcings from historical emissions, and its temperature response, which matches the GMT constraint with a lower ECS, higher ocean heat content and increased aerosol cooling, relative to proxy assessments (Supplementary Fig. 1). These approximations introduce biases in projections relative to CMIP6: SNEASY can underestimate the upper tail of the temperature distributions associated with the canonical SSP-RCP scenarios (Supplementary Table 1).BRICK also has biases relative to the GMT and (medium-confidence) SLR projections from the IPCC Sixth Assessment Report (AR6)48 which are relevant for contextualizing the projections in this study, namely a smaller upper tail of effective climate sensitivity, including both the carbon-cycle and energy-balance components (Supplementary Table 1), and higher SLR estimates at temperatures above 3 °C, largely due to higher inferred GIS sensitivity and the AIS fast dynamics mechanism (Supplementary Fig. 2); some of these differences may also be attributed to the inclusion in the AR6 projections of only processes that are considered medium-confidence, which may neglect some hypothesized accelerated melting mechanisms present in BRICK. These SLR biases are consistent with previous comparisons of SLR model families40.SOW generationFor each emissions scenario, we generate 100,000 SOWs by combining a draw from the corresponding emissions distribution and a draw from the joint probability distribution of the geophysical parameters obtained from the SNEASY–DOECLIM–BRICK calibration. This ensures that correlations in the geophysical models are maintained. Each combined parameter sample is used to simulate the full emissions–climate–sea-level chain from 1850 to 2023. Residuals are added to each of the simulated geophysical time series based on the calibrated AR(1) statistical model to produce the final simulated ‘observations’. The resulting GMSLR and temperature distributions are shown in Extended Data Fig. 1 and Supplementary Fig. 9.Transient sensitivity estimationTo estimate the transient sensitivity of GMSLR to emissions and temperatures, we fitted a linear regression model with a breakpoint GMT0 using the GLM.jl Julia package56. For example, for the GMT regression,$${\rm{G}}{\rm{M}}{\rm{S}}{\rm{L}}{\rm{R}}=a+b\times {I}_{{\rm{G}}{\rm{M}}{\rm{T}} > {\rm{G}}{\rm{M}}{\rm{T}}}+{c}_{0}\times {\rm{G}}{\rm{M}}{\rm{T}}+\varepsilon ,\,\,\,\,\,\,\varepsilon \approx N(0,{\sigma }^{2}),$$
                    (2)
                where IGMT>GMT0 is the indicator function with value 1 if GMT > GMT0 and 0 otherwise.Breakpoints were identified by searching over fitted models with candidate break points between 0 and 4 °C and selecting the model that minimized the model deviance.It is not appropriate to directly use the P-value for the fitted breakpoint estimate (< 1 × 10−99 for both models) to draw conclusions about the statistical significance of the identified breakpoint owing to having tested multiple candidate breakpoints. To determine whether the breakpoint model is statistically significant, we generated 10,000 alternative datasets under the assumption of a fitted null linear model without a breakpoint and repeated the breakpoint-finding procedure. We then looked at the maximum (across the null model fits) P-value of the breakpoint parameter to estimate the probability of falsely finding a spurious breakpoint under the null no-breakpoint model. None of the null-data breakpoint coefficient P-values from the alternative fitted models were as small as the P-value fitted to the original ensemble, and therefore we conclude that the identified breakpoint is statistically significant.Feature importanceWe calculate the importance of different features in the full model chain using Shapley indices, a game-theoretic approach to factor ranking31. Shapley indices measure the contribution of a ‘coalition’ of parameters to predicting model simulations when these indices are allowed to vary, rather than being fixed at their expected value(s). The Shapley indices are computed every five years from 2050 to 2200.To compute the Shapley indices from our ensemble of SOWs, we use EvoTrees.jl57 and MLJ.jl58 to fit a regression boosted decision tree to predict GMSLR for the given year based on the SOW. The boosted tree uses 200 sequentially stacked trees, with each tree in the random forest limited to five levels to reduce the risk of overfitting while incorporating a moderate number of interactions between parameters59.We then use the ShapML.jl Julia package60, which implements a sampling-based estimator of the indices61, which makes no assumptions about factor dependence, to estimate the Shapley indices based on the associated boosted tree. We use 100 Monte Carlo samples for each data point (corresponding to a single model evaluation) in the estimator; preliminary tests showed only minimal changes in the resulting indices between 50 and 100 samples. As Shapley indices are additive, we compute aggregate indices for each model component by averaging the absolute value of indices for all groups. In addition to the explicit emissions and geophysical groups, the ‘other’ group corresponds to unmodelled processes, captured through the model residuals.Scenario discoveryWe use classification boosted trees, trained using the EvoTrees.jl57 and MLJ.jl58 Julia packages on the peaking ensemble, to generate factor maps of the probability of exceeding the selected thresholds. The boosted tree was generated by stacking 200 decision trees, each limited to a depth of three levels. We then generated predictions using the trained forests by varying the peaking year and using a grid of AIS threshold temperatures and equilibrium climate sensitivities with a step size of 0.01 across their ranges from the calibrated SNEASY–BRICK parameter distribution.Uncertainty and anomaly reportingAll temperatures and sea levels are presented as anomalies from a given reference period. For GMTs, this reference is the mean value over the 1850–1900 period, and for sea levels, we use the global sea-level mean from 1995 to 2015.Credible and projection intervals are commonly given as the central 90% interval, from the 5% to 95% percentiles. We report posterior probabilities as whole percentages.

Data availability
            
            All input data used for the analysis are available with the code (in the data folder) except for the SNEASY–BRICK calibration results, which available from Zenodo via https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.6626335 (ref. 62) (see the GitHub README for guidance on which file to use). Simulation outputs from this experiment are available from Zenodo via https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.10373089 (ref. 63). Outputs for BRICK when forced by the Shared Socioeconomic Pathways are available from Zenodo via https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.14346558 (ref. 64).
          Code availability
            
            All code used for this analysis is available from Zenodo via https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.10391373 (ref. 65). This code is available under a GNU General Public License v.3.0.

items.title: Mountain glaciers recouple to atmospheric warming over the twenty-first century
items.body:

Mountain glaciers recouple to atmospheric warming over the twenty-first century
                    Thomas E. Shaw
